doc.abstracts: This report is the eleventh in the series of annual reports on key issues of development. The first part examines the recent trends in the global economy and what it means for the prospects of countries in development. The second part looks at the role of public finance in development. As in previous years, the Report contains the appended Development Indicators in the world, which have different social and economic statistics for over 100 countries. The expansion of the global economy recorded in 1987 continued in 1988, but two problems characterized recent trends: the unsustainable economic imbalances observed both within the industrial countries and between these countries and the strong inequality of economic growth in developing countries. The first part of the Report concludes the necessity to focus on three interdependent objectives. First, industrial countries should reduce the imbalances in their external payments, otherwise the world economy as a whole, and particularly of developing countries, could be seriously threatened with a recession and financial turmoil. Second, developing countries must continue to restructure their own policies to improve their economic solvency and accelerate their growth. Third, net transfers of resources of developing countries to the rest of the world must be reduced to revive investment and growth. Continued adjustment in industrial countries as in developing countries, play a useful role. The analysis stresses that the fight against poverty remains the ultimate goal of any policy of development. It adds that it is essential that fiscal policy maintains stable economic growth and is essential to reducing poverty in the long term. The report concludes that if properly oriented, spending serves to broaden public access for the poor to essential services, protection costs for social adjustment and supports the development of uman resources.
